answers.answer: What I am thinking is, there are so many here who are absolutely terrified about what interferon might do to us, but if we think back on the stuff we used to shoot into ourselves by IV drug use, not knowing really what was going into our veins, how come we are so scared today, we weren't then.

I call it at first young and stupid....than addicted!  Fortunatley I never made it past the young and stupid part.  I have wondered how a person that was once addicted handles having to now use syringes, does it tempt/remind them of the addiction?And yep, God only knows what was really in some of that street 'rewards' stuff !(along with this virus!) But we DO know what's in these shots....and sure don't crave them!LL

Peg really isn't even injected intramuscular - it's injected subcutaneously or beneath the skin. That's a far cry from intravenous and a lot less painful than intramuscular from my limited experience. Mike

Yes that may be another difference, I've had way too much experience even with muscling so doing it like a TB shot will be different and the stomach will be different as well.  They're still needles, I don't see how it could tempt anyone as there isn't a reward escept for clearing the virus and that won't wake anything up for me at all.  I'm just thinking that it's ironic and wish there was a different way.  If you have a good support system and you're confident in your sobriety then I don't see a problem with it as far as tempting anyone.  I'll be fine cause I want to put an end to this black cloud hovering over my life, so I'll do what I gotta do.    God Bless

Maybe fret, it's to shake the association of needles and IV drug use.  When I first learned that I had to do an injection once a week, I thought of the son of my friends, he has diabetes and he's been injecting daily since he was a boy.  So injecting is good AND bad .. and for once...you're on the good side, along with those with diabetes and Elaine's son Nick and all that.  It IS very different, no looking for a vein, you "pinch an inch" and away you go.  I hope it goes well for you.Trish

I have heard of  an inteferon junki. I actually know one his name is Karl like snoppys master. This guy whos in his sixties quite a funny type (bit of a hillbilly) . He said when he was doing tx, that it reminded him of the good old days when he was shooting up some speed.So when he took that shot in the stomach he even felt a little horny! He really locked forward to that moment every week.If thats not a inteferon junkii I dont know what is.The brain is a funny thing, and its capacity of suggestion never stop to baffle me! LOLAnd he had those peginteferon pens dosen´t even look like something  suggestivable.Of course this guy cleared the virus.To be serios, theres an old saying that goes, ones an opened vena will never close again.I don´t think that is the whole truth but there is some truth in it.And we who had been doing that, open them venas, we shouldn´t get to surprised, if we get crazy thougths even after long time not using.My vena has been closed for 21years (if its possible to get them closed)Today forinstance when taking my 19th shot this sec tx I´ve got this crazy thought that not to destroy my pegasus injection thing and instead save it for a rainy day .If you are figthing for better environment, reuse is not such a bad thing, I thought!But those thoughts its like birds flying over your head, and maybe they always will fly there. And there is nothing you can do about it.But even if you can´t stop them from flying , you can hopingly prevent them from building a nest in your head.And thats exactly  what I did.I simply destroyed there building material by clipping the needle and throwing the other stuff in a little plastic box that the hospital so kindly had  provided me with.Take care and may the good God bless and protect you.ca

"So injecting is good AND bad .. and for once...you're on the good side, along with those with diabetes and Elaine's son Nick and all"  Yeah I like being a good guy, I can live with that.  I'm a hard working tax payer and I actually like being a part of the working class.  It's actually gotten really hip to be alive and live a good honest life.  It really makes me appreciate it even more when I run into someone I used to know in my old neighborhood.  I can feel from them and myself how much we have grown apart.  Although I ask them how's their health, we really don't talk of anything past that, as we really don't have anything in common anymore.  God Blesscomeagain, I never did like speed, but I get the message thanks for your words of encouragement.  I especially like this "may the good God bless and protect you".  Same to you, all.

I never really had anything against needles. But now, thinking that I'll have to jab myself in the stomach or thighs once a week, makes my stomach turn around. I don't know why, but it's happening and it makes me feel sick. And then thinking that my 18 year old daughter will have to do it. Ouch.... I hope she won't ask me to do it for her. I'm usually not a chicken, but i don't know what's come over me.  I'm sure when the time comes, this will be the very last thing to worry about. Who knows, I might enjoy it, like Karl in Sweden.Marcia

For me, the needles disappear in the complexity of the side effects.  As other people have said, the jab is subcutaneous and only takes a few seconds; the side effects of the drug overwhelm the rest of the week!

" have heard of  an inteferon junki. I actually know one his name is Karl like snoppys master. This guy whos in his sixties quite a funny type (bit of a hillbilly) . He said when he was doing tx, that it reminded him of the good old days when he was shooting up some speed. "It's funny, but while I never used drugs intraveinously, I can understand this a little. There was a certain feeling that goes with interferon, for me, a buzzing, pounding head, and moodiness. It wasn't that pleasent, but over time, I started to anticipate it during treatment. I think about it still now, and in a way, I do sort of miss it sometimes, as crazy as that sounds.

I hate needels to! I never liked speed that much either!I took it for 12 years, mostly when I was drunk and  wanted a quick way to gett rid of the fuddle.Trish what you said was so beautiful I almost fall in love with you for them words.Andiamo you are the wise man you said it all! and with them short words, you took us back to earth thx for that.Moa you made me think, brave of you to tell us your  thoughts ty.Marcia you will do what you gotta do no problem.This man Karl, to be honest i think he was pulling my leg a little bit, I thougt i saw a twinkle in is eye when he told that story.But you never know with Karl he never tells if joke or not.I got to say something to you child 24 angel (elaine) also. I dont no your  (your sons boths) story that well, I know its a tuff one though.I´ve seen some of your comments to others post lately and you always have a loving supporting word to everyone.Thats make you angellike in my eyes.God bless you, your son and everybody els who has been writing in on this thread.fretboard ! I really liked that  you liked, the blessing and protection part.
Treatment? Someday I'll take a poke at it.

question: Does anyone find it a little ironic that some of us got HepC using IV and now we have to treat ourselves with IV to treat this HepC?  Doesn't anyone find that just a little bothersome?  I know the man upstairs has a sense of humor, but give me a break.  I hate needles!  I don't hate them exactly there was a time when I liked them, but back in the day I was being rewarded.  Just because you use to use IV doesn't mean you like needles, using dope is alot different than using interferon.  Has anyone ever heard of an interferon junkie?  I don't think so!  Anybody have any ideas on this subject?  Hey since there's such a big stigma with this virus I figure, I put my playing hand on the table and take what I get.  Be kind though, I'm just trying to put a face on this virus which I'm finding out is like a dog chasing his tail.  God Bless you
title: IV use before and after, what a deal?
